Author: Henry David Thoreau,  Thoreau Journal 9
Quote: What sort of philosophers are we, who know absolutely nothing of the origin and destiny of cats?

Author: Plato,  Theaetetus
Quote: For this feeling of wonder shows that you are a philosopher, since wonder is the only beginning of philosophy.

Author: Jean-Paul Sartre,  Existentialism Is a Humanism
Quote: In life man commits himself and draws his own portrait, outside of which there is nothing. No doubt this thought may seem harsh to someone who has not made a success of his life. But on the other hand, it helps people to understand that reality alone counts, and that dreams, expectations and hopes only serve to define a man as a broken dream, aborted hopes, and futile expectations.

Author: Benny Bellamacina,  The King of Rhyme
Quote: If you wake up tired, you’ve been chasing dreams. If you go to bed tired, your making your dreams happen.

Author: Rebecca Solnit,  A Field Guide to Getting Lost
Quote: Leave the door open for the unknown, the door into the dark. That’s where the most important things come from, where you yourself came from, and where you will go.

Author: Elaine May
Quote: The only safe thing is to take a chance.

Author: Philip Pullman,  His Dark Materials Trilogy: The Golden Compass / The Subtle Knife / The Amber Spyglass
Quote: People should decide on the books' meanings for themselves. They'll find a story that attacks such things as cruelty, oppression, intolerance, unkindness, narrow-mindedness, and celebrates love, kindness, open-mindedness, tolerance, curiosity, human intelligence.

Author: Haruki Murakami,  A Wild Sheep Chase
Quote: Whether you take the doughnut hole as a blank space or as an entity unto itself is a purely metaphysical question and does not affect the taste of the doughnut one bit.

Author: Edith Sitwell
Quote: Eccentricity is not, as some would believe, a form of madness. It is often a kind of innocent pride, and the man of genius and the aristocrat are frequently regarded as eccentrics because genius and aristocrat are entirely unafraid of and uninfluenced by the opinions and vagaries of the crowd.

Author: Blaise Pascal
Quote: To ridicule philosophy is really to philosophize.

Author: Karl Popper
Quote: No rational argument will have a rational effect on a man who does not want to adopt a rational attitude.

Author: W. Somerset Maugham,  The Razor's Edge
Quote: Nothing in the world is permanent, and we’re foolish when we ask anything to last, but surely we’re still more foolish not to take delight in it while we have it. If change is of the essence of existence one would have thought it only sensible to make it the premise of our philosophy.

Author: Aristotle,  Poetics
Quote: Comedy aims at representing men as worse, Tragedy as better than in actual life.

Author: Søren Kierkegaard,  Fear and Trembling
Quote: If there were no eternal consciousness in a man, if at the bottom of everything there were only a wild ferment, a power that twisting in dark passions produced everything great or inconsequential; if an unfathomable, insatiable emptiness lay hid beneath everything, what would life be but despair?

Author: George Sterling
Quote: A prison becomes a home when you have the key.

Author: Robert Thier,  Storm and Silence
Quote: Knowledge is power is time is money.

Author: Baruch Spinoza
Quote: I have made a ceaseless effort not to ridicule, not to bewail, not to scorn human actions, but to understand them.

Author: Carlos Ruiz Zafón,  The Shadow of the Wind
Quote: Few things are more deceptive than memories.

Author: Miyamoto Musashi,  The Book of Five Rings
Quote: The primary thing when you take a sword in your hands is your intention to cut the enemy, whatever the means. Whenever you parry, hit, spring, strike or touch the enemy's cutting sword, you must cut the enemy in the same movement. It is essential to attain this. If you think only of hitting, springing, striking or touching the enemy, you will not be able actually to cut him.

Author: Antonio Gramsci
Quote: The point of modernity is to live a life without illusions while not becoming disillusioned

Author: Thomas Jefferson
Quote: There is nothing more unequal than the equal treatment of unequal people.

Author: John Green,  Paper Towns
Quote: Imagine others complexly.

Author: Virginia Woolf,  Orlando
Quote: No passion is stronger in the breast of a man than the desire to make others believe as he believes. Nothing so cuts at the root of his happiness and fills him with rage as the sense that another rates low what he prizes high.

Author: George Harrison
Quote: Show me that I m everywhere and get me home for tea.

Author: Alexandre Dumas,  The Count of Monte Cristo
Quote: Philosophy cannot be taught; it is the application of the sciences to truth.

Author: Phillip C. McGraw
Quote: Life's managed, not cured.

Author: Peter Kreeft
Quote: Cats don't need to be possessed; they're evil on their own.

Author: Terry Pratchett,  Small Gods
Quote: We are here and it is now. The way I see it is, after that, everything tends towards guesswork.

Author: Robert Anton Wilson,  Cosmic Trigger Volume I: Final Secret of the Illuminati
Quote: ...reality is always plural and mutable.

Author: Aristotle,  Nicomachean Ethics
Quote: Philosophy can make people sick.

Author: Joyce Carol Oates
Quote: And this is the forbidden truth, the unspeakable taboo - that evil is not always repellent but frequently attractive; that it has the power to make of us not simply victims, as nature and accident do, but active accomplices.

Author: Martin Heidegger,  Introduction to Metaphysics
Quote: Why are there beings at all, instead of Nothing?

Author: Heraclitus,  Fragments
Quote: Wisdom is the oneness of mind that guides and permeated all things.

Author: Daisaku Ikeda
Quote: Reality is harsh. It can be cruel and ugly. Yet no matter how much we grieve over our environment and circumstances nothing will change. What is important is not to be defeated, to forge ahead bravely. If we do this, a path will open before us.

Author: Jiddu Krishnamurti,  Freedom from the Known
Quote: Thought is so cunning, so clever, that it distorts everything for its own convenience.

Author: René Descartes,  The Principles of Philosophy
Quote: I desire to live in peace and to continue the life I have begun under the motto 'to live well you must live unseen

Author: Epicurus
Quote: Never say that I have taken it, only that I have given it back.

Author: Robert Anton Wilson,  Cosmic Trigger Volume I: Final Secret of the Illuminati
Quote: We look for the Secret - the Philosopher's Stone, the Elixir of the Wise, Supreme Enlightenment, 'God' or whatever...and all the time it is carrying us about...It is the human nervous system itself.

Author: Graham Greene
Quote: Despair is the price one pays for setting oneself an impossible aim. It is, one is told, the unforgivable sin, but it is a sin the corrupt or evil man never practices. He always has hope. He never reaches the freezing-point of knowing absolute failure. Only the man of goodwill carries always in his heart this capacity for damnation.

Author: Rabindranath Tagore
Quote: YOU are the big drop of dew under the lotus leaf, I am the smaller one on its upper side,'said the dewdrop to the lake.

Author: Shunryu Suzuki,  Zen Mind, Beginner's Mind: Informal Talks on Zen Meditation and Practice
Quote: In the beginner’s mind there are many possibilities, but in the expert’s there are few

Author: Ki Longfellow,  Flow Down Like Silver: Hypatia of Alexandria
Quote: What comes, is called.

Author: J.D. Salinger,  Nine Stories
Quote: You asked me how to get out of the finite dimensions when I feel like it. I certainly don't use logic when I do it. Logic's the first thing you have to get rid of.

Author: Stephen Hawking
Quote: What I have done is to show that it is possible for the way the universe began to be determined by the laws of science. In that case, it would not be necessary to appeal to God to decide how the universe began. This doesn't prove that there is no God, only that God is not necessary.

Author: Aberjhani,  The River of Winged Dreams
Quote: Un-winged and naked, sorrow surrenders its crown to a throne called grace.

Author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau
Quote: Everything is good as it comes from the hands of the Maker of the world, but degenerates once it gets into the hands of man

Author: Terry Pratchett,  Small Gods
Quote: The trouble was that he was talking in philosophy but they were listening in gibberish.

Author: René Magritte
Quote: Everything we see hides another thing, we always want to see what is hidden by what we see, but it is impossible. Humans hide their secrets too well....

Author: Ludwig Wittgenstein
Quote: How small a thought it takes to fill a life.

Author: John Fowles,  The Collector
Quote: When you draw something it lives and when you photograph it it dies

Author: Guy Debord
Quote: Young people everywhere have been allowed to choose between love and a garbage disposal unit. Everywhere they have chosen the garbage disposal unit.

Author: John Stuart Mill,  On Liberty
Quote: If all mankind minus one, were of one opinion, and only one person were of the contrary opinion, mankind would be no more justified in silencing that one person, than he, if he had the power, would be justified in silencing mankind.

Author: Terry Pratchett,  Wintersmith
Quote: I’m not superstitious. I’m a witch. Witches aren’t superstitious. We are what people are superstitious of.

Author: R.A. Salvatore
Quote: Change is not always growth, but growth is often rooted in change.Drizzt Do'Urden

Author: Fulton J. Sheen
Quote: Too many people get credit for being good, when they are only being passive. They are too often praised for being broadminded when they are so broadminded they can never make up their minds about anything.

Author: Peter Kreeft,  Jesus-Shock
Quote: The heart is like a woman, and the head is like a man, and although man is the head of woman, woman is the heart of man, and she turns man's head because she turns his heart.

Author: Madeleine L'Engle
Quote: It takes too much energy to be against something unless it's really important.

Author: Arthur Rubinstein
Quote: Of course there is no formula for success, except perhaps an unconditional acceptance of life, and what it brings

Author: Dave Eggers,  A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius
Quote: If you don't want anyone to know about your existence, you might as well kill yourself. You're taking up space, air.

Author: Flannery O'Connor
Quote: If you live today, you breath in nihilism ... it's the gas you breathe. If I hadn't had the Church to fight it with or to tell me the necessity of fighting it, I would be the stinkingest logical positivist you ever saw right now.

Author: Ayn Rand,  Atlas Shrugged
Quote: I do not think that tragedy is our natural fate and I do not live in chronic dread of disaster. It is no happiness, but suffering that I consider unnatural. It is not success, but calamity that I regard as the abnormal exception in Human Life.

Author: Antonio Machado
Quote: Between living and dreaming there is a third thing. Guess it.

Author: Bob Proctor,  You Were Born Rich
Quote: Thoughts become things. If you see it in your mind, you will hold it in your hand.

Author: Jodi Picoult,  My Sister's Keeper
Quote: You know how the tightrope guy at the circus wants everyone to believe his act is an art, but deep down you can see that he's really just hoping he makes it all the way across?

Author: Mark Lawrence,  King of Thorns
Quote: We’re built of contradictions, all of us. It’s those opposing forces that give us strength, like an arch, each block pressing the next. Give me a man whose parts are all aligned in agreement and I’ll show you madness. We walk a narrow path, insanity to each side. A man without contradictions to balance him will soon veer off.

Author: Carlos Ruiz Zafón,  The Angel's Game
Quote: Nothing important is learned; it is simply remembered.

Author: Marcus Aurelius,  Meditations
Quote: If someone can prove me wrong and show me my mistake in any thought or action, I shall gladly change. I seek the truth, which never harmed anyone: the harm is to persist in one's own self-deception and ignorance.

Author: Alexander McCall Smith,  The No. 1 Ladies' Detective Agency
Quote: It was time to take the pumpkin out of the pot and eat it. In the final analysis, that was what solved these big problems of life. You could think and think and get nowhere, but you still had to eat your pumpkin. That brought you down to earth. That gave you a reason for going on. Pumpkin.

Author: George Orwell,  Animal Farm
Quote: Windmill or no windmill, he said, life would go on as it had always gone on--that is, badly.

Author: Novalis
Quote: Philosophy is really nostalgia, the desire to be at home.

Author: Martin Heidegger,  Being and Time
Quote: Everyone is the other and no one is himself.

Author: Jorge Luis Borges,  Labyrinths: Selected Stories and Other Writings
Quote: Whatever one man does, it is as if all men did it. For that reason, it is not unfair that one disobedience in a garden should contaminate all humanity; for that reason it is not unjust that the crucifixion of a single Jew should be sufficient to save it.

Author: Kurt Vonnegut,  God Bless You, Mr. Rosewater
Quote: There's only one rule that I know of, babies—God damn it, you've got to be kind.

Author: José Martí
Quote: A child who does not think about what happens around him and is content with living without wondering whether he lives honestly is like a man who lives from a scoundrel's work and is on the road to being a scoundrel.

Author: René Daumal
Quote: This place has only three exits, sir: Madness, and Death.

Author: Peter Kreeft,  Jesus-Shock
Quote: By the way, if you get mad at your Mac laptop and wonder who designed this demonic device, notice the manufacturer's icon on top: an apple with a bite out of it.

Author: Voltaire
Quote: L'homme est libre au moment qu'il veut l'être.

Author: Nassim Nicholas Taleb
Quote: Things always become obvious after the fact

Author: Socrates
Quote: I only know that I know nothing

Author: Voltaire
Quote: The discovery of what is true and the practice of that which is good are the two most important aims of philosophy.

Author: فولتير
Quote: الكتب كالبشر .. قليل منها يلعب دورا عظيما

Author: Thomas Aquinas
Quote: The Study of philosophy is not that we may know what men have thought, but what the truth of things is.

Author: Knut Hamsun,  Hunger
Quote: Truth is neither ojectivity nor the balanced view; truth is a selfless subjectivity.

Author: Jess C. Scott,  The Darker Side of Life
Quote: The brightest light casts the darkest shadow.

Author: Peter Kreeft,  Jesus-Shock
Quote: Our culture has filled our heads but emptied our hearts, stuffed our wallets but starved our wonder. It has fed our thirst for facts but not for meaning or mystery. It produces "nice"people, not heroes.

Author: Eric Hoffer,  The Temper of Our Time
Quote: Every great cause begins as a movement, becomes a business, and eventually degenerates into a racket.

Author: Langston Hughes
Quote: Yet the ivory gods, And the ebony gods, And the gods of diamond-jade, Are only silly puppet gods That people themselves Have made.-

Author: W.B. Yeats
Quote: People who lean on logic and philosophy and rational exposition end by starving the best part of the mind.

Author: Plato
Quote: False words are not only evil in themselves, but they infect the soul with evil.

Author: Ryokan
Quote: Too lazy to be ambitious,I let the world take care of itself.Ten days' worth of rice in my bag;a bundle of twigs by the fireplace.Why chatter about delusion and enlightenment?Listening to the night rain on my roof,I sit comfortably, with both legs stretched out.

Author: Bob Dylan,  Chronicles, Vol. 1
Quote: There's only one day at a time here, then it's tonight and then tomorrow will be today again.

Author: Philip James Bailey,  Festus: A Poem
Quote: We live in deeds not years In thoughts not breaths In feelings not figures on a dial. We should count time by heart throbs. He most lives who thinks most, feels noblest, acts the best.

Author: Barbara Kingsolver,  The Poisonwood Bible
Quote: To live is to change, to acquire the words of a story, and that is the only celebration we mortals really know.

Author: Carroll Bryant
Quote: Nothing is as it seems, but something is everything it is made out to be.

Author: Dale Carnegie
Quote: you can measure the size of a person by what makes him or her angry

Author: Immanuel Kant,  An Answer to the Question: What Is Enlightenment?
Quote: But only he who, himself enlightened, is not afraid of shadows.

Author: Rick Riordan
Quote: Hope does not leave without being given permission.

Author: Dan Millman,  Way of the Peaceful Warrior: A Book That Changes Lives
Quote: The world's a puzzle; no need to make sense out of it."- Socrates

Author: Emil Cioran
Quote: To live entirely without a goal! I have glimpsed this state, and have often attained it, without managing to remain there: I am too weak for such happiness.

Author: Noah Benshea,  Jacob the Baker: Gentle Wisdom For a Complicated World
Quote: My heart knows what my mind only think it knows.

Author: Okakura Kakuzō,  The Book of Tea
Quote: Teaism is a cult founded on the adoration of the beautiful among the sordid facts of everyday existence. It inculcates purity and harmony, the mystery of mutual charity, the romanticism of the social order. It is essentially a worship of the Imperfect, as it is a tender attempt to accomplish something possible in this impossible thing we know as life.

Author: Black Elk,  Black Elk Speaks: Being the Life Story of a Holy Man of the Oglala Sioux
Quote: Crazy Horse dreamed and went into the world where there is nothing but the spirits of all things. That is the real world that is behind this one, and everything we see here is something like a shadow from that one.

Author: Henry James,  Roderick Hudson
Quote: True happiness, we are told, consists in getting out of one's self; but the point is not only to get out - you must stay out; and to stay out you must have some absorbing errand.

Author: C.T. Studd
Quote: Some want to live within the soundOf church or chapel bell;I want to run a rescue shop,Within a yard of hell.

Author: Kurt Vonnegut,  The Sirens of Titan
Quote: Mankind flung its advance agents ever outward, ever outward. Eventually it flung them out into space, into the colorless, tasteless, weightless sea of outwardness without end. It flung them like stones.

Author: Confucius
Quote: No lake so still but it has its wave.No circle so perfect but that it has its blur.I would change things for you if I could; As I can't you must take them as they are.

Author: William S. Burroughs
Quote: To be an outlaw you must first have a base in law to reject and get out of, I never had such a base. I never had a place I could call home that meant any more than a key to a house, apartment or hotel room. … Am I alien? Alien from what exactly? Perhaps my home is my dream city, more real than my waking life precisely because it has no relation to waking life…

Author: Elie Wiesel
Quote: The opposite of love is not hate, it's indifference.

Author: Aleister Crowley,  Diary of a Drug Fiend
Quote: I've often thought that there isn't any "I"at all; that we are simply the means of expression of something else; that when we think we are ourselves, we are simply the victims of a delusion.

Author: Eliezer Yudkowsky,  Harry Potter and the Methods of Rationality
Quote: There is no justice in the laws of nature, no term for fairness in the equations of motion. The Universe is neither evil, nor good, it simply does not care. The stars don't care, or the Sun, or the sky. But they don't have to! WE care! There IS light in the world, and it is US!

Author: Ray Bradbury,  Fahrenheit 451
Quote: Digression is the soul of wit. Take the philosophic asides away from Dante, Milton or Hamlet's father's ghost and what stays is dry bones.

Author: Jasper Fforde,  One of Our Thursdays Is Missing
Quote: For every expert there is an equal and opposite expert.

Author: Douglas Coupland,  The Gum Thief
Quote: A few years ago it dawned on me that everybody past a certain age ... pretty much constantly dreams of being able to escape from their lives. They don't want to be who they are any more. They want out. This list includes Thurston Howell the Third, Ann-Margret, the cat members of Rent, Václav Havel, space shuttle astronauts and Snuffleupagus. It's universal.

Author: Martin Heidegger
Quote: Thinking only begins at the point where we have come to know that Reason, glorified for centuries, is the most obstinate adversary of thinking.

Author: Elias Canetti
Quote: All things one has forgotten scream for help in dreams.

Author: Daniel Quinn,  Ishmael: An Adventure of the Mind and Spirit
Quote: The premise of the Taker story is 'the world belongs to man'. … The premise of the Leaver story is 'man belongs to the world'.

Author: Bertrand Russell,  A History of Western Philosophy
Quote: Almost everything that distinguishes the modern world from earlier centuries is attibutable to science, which achieved its most spectacular triumphs in the seventeenth century.

Author: John Dewey
Quote: Give the pupils something to do, not something to learn; and the doing is of such a nature as to demand thinking; learning naturally results.

Author: Solange nicole
Quote: Sometimes... Reason and Love are met with a violent ignorance that even what's right gets lost. Our heart bleeds, but when does the blood shed end and the healing begin?

Author: Jostein Gaarder,  The Solitaire Mystery
Quote: Although you may not stumble across a Martian in the garden, you might stumble across yourself. The day that happens, you'll probably also scream a little. And that'll be perfectly all right, because it's not every day you realize you're a living planet dweller on a little island in the universe.

Author: G.K. Chesterton
Quote: Science must not impose any philosophy, any more than the telephone must tell us what to say.

Author: Niccolò Machiavelli,  The Prince
Quote: Men ought either to be well treated or crushed, because they can avenge themselves of lighter injuries, of more serious ones they cannot; therefore the injury that is to be done to a man ought to be of such a kind that one does not stand in fear of revenge.

Author: Shunryu Suzuki,  Zen Is Right Here: Teaching Stories and Anecdotes of Shunryu Suzuki, Author of "ZEN Mind, Beginner's Mind"
Quote: A student, filled with emotion and crying, implored, "Why is there so much suffering?"Suzuki Roshi replied, "No reason.

Author: Peter Kreeft,  Jesus-Shock
Quote: We sinned for no reason but an incomprehensible lack of love, and He saved us for no reason but an incomprehensible excess of love.

Author: Plato,  The Allegory of the Cave
Quote: How could they see anything but the shadows if they were never allowed to move their heads?

Author: Marquis de Sade,  Justine, Philosophy in the Bedroom, and Other Writings
Quote: The man who alters his way of thinking to suit others is a fool.

Author: Marion Zimmer Bradley,  The Mists of Avalon
Quote: By what men think, we create the world around us, daily new.

Author: Heraclitus,  Fragments
Quote: People ought to fight to keep their law as to defend the citys walls.

Author: Melissa Marr,  Ink Exchange
Quote: In the end mortals always expired before faeries. They were such finite creatures. Their first heartbeat and breath were but a blink from death. To add the weight of nourishing his insatiable court in a time of peace was to hasten that unconscionably.

Author: Slavoj Žižek,  Tarrying with the Negative: Kant, Hegel, and the Critique of Ideology
Quote: as soon as we renounce fiction and illusion, we lose reality itself; the moment we subtract fictions from reality, reality itself loses its discursive-logical consistency.

Author: Honoré de Balzac,  Père Goriot
Quote: Who is to decide which is the grimmer sight: withered hearts, or empty skulls?

Author: Thomas Aquinas
Quote: Because philosophy arises from awe, a philosopher is bound in his way to be a lover of myths and poetic fables. Poets and philosophers are alike in being big with wonder.

Author: Frank Herbert,  God Emperor of Dune
Quote: The truth always carries the ambiguity of the words used to express it.

Author: Pete Hamill
Quote: There are 10,000 books in my library, and it will keep growing until I die. This has exasperated my daughters, amused my friends and baffled my accountant. If I had not picked up this habit in the library long ago, I would have more money in the bank today; I would not be richer.

Author: Paul Sweeney
Quote: How can a society that exists on instant mashed potatoes, packaged cake mixes, frozen dinners, and instant cameras teach patience to its young?

Author: Dirk Wittenborn,  Fierce People
Quote: We are the sum of all people we have ever met; you change the tribe and the tribe changes you.

Author: Gilles Deleuze
Quote: The shame of being a man - is there any better reason to write?

Author: Joseph Campbell,  A Joseph Campbell Companion: Reflections on the Art of Living
Quote: You become mature when you become the authority of your own life.

Author: K. Crumley
Quote: Some day people will ask me what is the key to my success...and I will simply say, "good Karma.

Author: Albert Camus
Quote: Those who lack the courage will always find a philosophy to justify it.

Author: Pier Paolo Pasolini
Quote: If you know that I am an unbeliever, then you know me better than I do myself. I may be an unbeliever, but I am an unbeliever who has a nostalgia for a belief.

Author: David Gemmell,  Sword in the Storm
Quote: It is hard to be angry when one has seen the sun rise,' she said.It seems to be true,' he admitted. 'I wonder why.'Because it makes one feel so small and insignificant. It has been rising forever and will rise forever no matter what we do or do not do. All our problems are as nothing to the sun.

Author: Sandy Nathan,  Numenon
Quote: I’ve always hated the “Who are you?"question. This is a philosophical inquiry. Answering that question is why we’re on earth. You can’t answer it in thirty seconds or in an elevator.

Author: Norman Maclean,  A River Runs Through It and Other Stories
Quote: Slowly we became silent, and silence itself if an enemy to friendship.

Author: Aberjhani,  Journey through the Power of the Rainbow: Quotations from a Life Made Out of Poetry
Quote: Love is our most unifying and empowering common spiritual denominator. The more we ignore its potential to bring greater balance and deeper meaning to human existence, the more likely we are to continue to define history as one long inglorious record of man’s inhumanity to man.

Author: Dee Lestari,  Madre: Kumpulan Cerita
Quote: Kendati batas antara kebebasan dan ketidakpedulian terkadang saru

Author: Ludwig Wittgenstein
Quote: We feel that even if all possible scientific questions be answered, the problems of life have still not been touched at all.

Author: Shel Silverstein
Quote: Rockabye Baby, in the treetopDont you know a treetopis no safe place to rock?And who put you up there,and your cradle too?Baby,I think someone down herehas got it in for you!

Author: أحمد خالد توفيق,  E.S.P.
Quote: ان الكتمان لنعمة, القناع الاجتماعى نعمة...لو وجد انسان قادر على رؤية الناس من غير ثياب فلابد انه سيموت من الاشمئزاز ..الثياب ضرورية جدا وكذا بعض الخصوصية

Author: Fulton J. Sheen,  Seven Words of Jesus and Mary: Lessons from Cana and Calvary
Quote: Never forget that there are only two philosophies to rule your life: the one of the cross, which starts with the fast and ends with the feast. The other of Satan, which starts with the feast and ends with the headache.

Author: Criss Jami,  Salomé: In Every Inch In Every Mile
Quote: Absurdity is the ecstasy of intellectualism.

Author: Marcus Aurelius,  Meditations
Quote: What we cannot bear removes us from life; what remains can be borne.

Author: Francis Bacon
Quote: Philosophy when superficially studied, excites doubt, when thoroughly explored, it dispels it.

Author: Bob Black,  The Abolition of Work & Other Essays
Quote: You are what you do. If you do boring, stupid monotonous work, chances are you'll end up boring, stupid and monotonous. Work is a much better explanation for the creeping cretinization all around us than even such significant moronizing mechanisms as television and education.

Author: Mahatma Gandhi
Quote: I have learnt through bitter experience the one supreme lesson to conserve my anger, and as heat conserved is transmuted into energy, even so our anger controlled can be transmuted into a power which can move the world.

Author: Bertrand Russell
Quote: Remember your humanity, and forget the rest.

Author: Jean-Paul Sartre
Quote: In football everything is complicated by the presence of the opposite team.

Author: Oscar Wilde,  The Picture of Dorian Gray
Quote: You are a wonderful creation. You know more than you think you know, just as you know less than you want to know.

Author: Socrates
Quote: My advice to you is get married: if you find a good wife you'll be happy; if not, you'll become a philosopher.

Author: Amish Tripathi,  The Oath of the Vayuputras
Quote: Creation and destruction are the two ends of the same moment. And everything between the creation and the next destruction is the journey of life.

Author: Hanh Nhat Thich,  The Miracle of Mindfulness: An Introduction to the Practice of Meditation
Quote: Those who are without compassion cannot see what is seen with the eyes of compassion.

Author: Jeremy Bentham
Quote: ...the rarest of all human qualities is consistency.

Author: George Steiner
Quote: when a language dies, a way of understanding the world dies with it, a way of looking at the world.

Author: David Olguín
Quote: Sin sorpresas, aunque sean disagredables, nadie estaria dispuesto a vivir.

Author: Peter Kreeft,  Jesus-Shock
Quote: This is the secret of life: the self lives only by dying, finds its identity (and its happiness) only by self-forgetfulness, self-giving, self-sacrifice, and agape love.

Author: Bill Watterson,  Calvin and Hobbes: Sunday Pages 1985-1995
Quote: Calvin:"It says here that 'religion is the opiate of the masses.'...what do you suppose that means?"Television: "...it means that Karl Marx hadn't seen anything yet

Author: William James,  The Varieties of Religious Experience
Quote: Good-humor is a philosophic state of mind; it seems to say to Nature that we take her no more seriously than she takes us. I maintain that one should always talk of philosophy with a smile.

Author: Al Munoz
Quote: If you're not happy in life then you need to change, calibrate, readjust...flush your negative energy and fill it with positive energy; How do we do that you might ask? well I would start by making others happy, deseases are not the only thing that spreads easy. We are all connected in some form of unseen energy... think how those around you will impact you and make you feel if they were happy?

Author: Shannon L. Alder
Quote: Beauty is not who you are on the outside, it is the wisdom and time you gave away to save another struggling soul, like you.

Author: Shunryu Suzuki
Quote: I discovered that it is necessary, absolutely necessary, to believe in nothing. That is, we have to believe in something which has no form and no color--something which exists before all forms and colors appear... No matter what god or doctrine you believe in, if you become attached to it, your belief will be based more or less on a self-centered idea.

Author: Shane Koyczan
Quote: Someone once told me that the finer points of devotion are about the size of a pinhole, and there are millions of them. And if you could connect each dot, then you’ve got a diagram of what you think you thought you knew, and if you’re willing to admit that you know nothing…you have the blueprint for a breakthrough.

Author: Bernard Beckett,  Genesis
Quote: Which came first, the mind or the idea of the mind? Have you never wondered? They arrived together. The mind is an idea.

Author: Thomas Merton
Quote: Pride makes us artificial; humility makes us real

Author: Peter Singer
Quote: What one generation finds ridiculous, the next accepts; and the third shudders when it looks back on what the first did.

Author: Noah Levine,  Dharma Punx: A Memoir
Quote: It's easy to hate and point out everything that is wrong with the world; it is the hardest and most important work in one's life to free oneself from the bonds of fear and attachment.

Author: Ian Somerhalder
Quote: Going green doesn’t start with doing green acts — it starts with a shift in consciousness. This shift allows you to recognize that with every choice you make, you are voting either for or against the kind of world you wish to see. When you assume this as a way of being, your choices become easier. Using a reusable water bottle, recycling and making conscious daily consumer choices are just a few…

Author: Sam Harris
Quote: The problem with religion, because it's been sheltered from criticism, is that it allows people to believe en masse what only idiots or lunatics could believe in isolation.

Author: Stephen King,  The Gunslinger
Quote: Few if any seemed to have grasped the Principle of Reality; new knowledge leads always to yet more awesome mysteries. Greater physiological knowledge of the brain makes the existence of the soul less possible yet more probable by the nature of the search.

Author: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe
Quote: Let mental culture go on advancing, let the natural sciences progress in even greater extent and depth, and the human mind widen itself as much as it desires: beyond the elevation and moral culture of Christianity, as it shines forth in the Gospels, it will not go.

Author: Shannon L. Alder
Quote: If you were born with the ability to change someone’s perspective or emotions, never waste that gift. It is one of the most powerful gifts God can give—the ability to influence.

Author: R. Scott Bakker,  The Darkness That Comes Before
Quote: The thoughts of all men arise from the darkness. If you are the movement of your soul, and the cause of that movement precedes you, then how could you ever call your thoughts your own? How could you be anything other than a slave to the darkness that comes before?

Author: François de La Rochefoucauld
Quote: Neither the sun nor death can be looked at steadily.

Author: José Martí
Quote: But love, like the sun that it is, sets afire and melts everything. what greed and privilege to build up over whole centuries the indignation of a pious spirit, with its natural following of oppressed souls, will cast down with a single shove.

Author: نجيب محفوظ,  حضرة المحترم
Quote: قال لنفسه إنه لا نجاة له إلا بالجنون. الجنون وحده هو الذي يتسع للإيمان والكفر، للمجد والخزي، للحب والخداع، للصدق والكذب، أما العقل فكيف يتحمل هذه الحياة الغريبة؟ كيف يشيم ألق النجوم وهو مغروس حتى قمة رأسه في الوحل؟!

Author: William Shakespeare,  Measure for Measure
Quote: Life... is a paradise to what we fear of death.

Author: Seneca,  Letters from a Stoic
Quote: Until we have begun to go without them, we fail to realize how unnecessary many things are. We've been using them not because we needed them but because we had them.

Author: Ravinder Singh
Quote: if you want it really, you get it !!!

Author: Plato,  Republic: The Theatre of the Mind
Quote: In practice people who study philosophy too long become very odd birds, not to say thoroughly vicious; while even those who are the best of them are reduced by...[philosophy] to complete uselessness as members of society.

Author: Kōbō Abe,  The Woman in the Dunes
Quote: Do you shovel to survive, or survive to shovel?

Author: Aberjhani,  The River of Winged Dreams
Quote: Love taught me to die with dignity that I might come forth anew in splendor. Born once of flesh, then again of fire, I was reborn a third time to the sound of my name humming haikus in heaven’s mouth.

Author: Robert M. Pirsig
Quote: In the high country of the mind one has to become adjusted to the thinner air of uncertainty...

Author: Friedrich Nietzsche,  Human, All Too Human
Quote: As soon as a religion comes to dominate it has as its opponents all those who would have been its first disciples.

Author: Ayn Rand
Quote: Anyone who fights for the future, lives in it today.

Author: Max Stirner
Quote: Whoever will be free must make himself free. Freedom is no fairy gift to fall into a man's lap. What is freedom? To have the will to be responsible for one's self.

Author: Lawrence M. Krauss,  A Universe from Nothing: Why There Is Something Rather Than Nothing
Quote: If we wish to draw philosophical conclusions about our own existence, our significance, and the significance of the universe itself, our conclusions should be based on empirical knowledge. A truly open mind means forcing our imaginations to conform to the evidence of reality, and not vice versa, whether or not we like the implications.

Author: Karl Marx,  The Communist Manifesto
Quote: Modern bourgeois society with its relations of production, of exchange, and of property, a society that has conjured up such gigantic means of production and of exchange, is like the sorcerer, who is no longer able to control the powers of the nether world whom he has called up by his spells.

Author: R. Dawkins,  The Blind Watchmaker
Quote: There is something infantile in the presumption that somebody else has a responsibility to give your life meaning and point… The truly adult view, by contrast, is that our life is as meaningful, as full and as wonderful as we choose to make it.

Author: Jessie B. Rittenhouse
Quote: I bargained with Life for a penny,And Life would pay no more, However I begged at eveningWhen I counted my scanty store;For Life is just an employer,He gives you what you ask,But once you have set the wages,Why, you must bear the task.I worked for a menial's hire,Only to learn, dismayed,That any wage I had asked of Life,Life would have paid.

Author: Ayn Rand
Quote: My philosophy, in essence, is the concept of man as a heroic being, with his own happiness as the moral purpose of his life, with productive achievement as his noblest activity, and reason as his only absolute.

Author: Samuel Beckett
Quote: I always thought old age would be a writer’s best chance. Whenever I read the late work of Goethe or W. B. Yeats I had the impertinence to identify with it. Now, my memory’s gone, all the old fluency’s disappeared. I don’t write a single sentence without saying to myself, ‘It’s a lie!’ So I know I was right. It’s the best chance I’ve ever had.

Author: Jostein Gaarder,  Sophie's World
Quote: And although I have seen nothing but black crows in my life, it doesn't mean that there's no such thing as a white crow. Both for a philosopher and for a scientist it can be important not to reject the possibility of finding a white crow. You might almost say that hunting for 'the white crow' is science's principal task.

Author: Milan Kundera,  The Unbearable Lightness of Being
Quote: The longing for Paradise is man's longing not to be man.

Author: Sapardi Djoko Damono
Quote: Waktu berjalan ke Barat di waktu pagi hari matahari mengikutiku di belakang.Aku berjalan mengikuti bayang-bayangku sendiri yang memanjang di depan.Aku dan matahari tidak bertengkar tentang siapa di antara kami yang telah menciptakan bayang-bayang,aku dan bayang-bayang tidak bertengkar tentang siapa di antara kami yang harus berjalan di depan.

Author: Robert Charles Wilson,  Spin
Quote: There are so many kinds of time. The time by which we measure our lives. Months and years. Or the big time, the time that raises mountains and makes stars. Or all the things that happen between one heartbeat and the next. Its hard to live in all those kinds of times. Easy to forget that you live in all of them.

Author: Bertrand Russell,  The Problems of Philosophy
Quote: Is there any knowledge in the world which is so certain that no reasonable man could doubt it?

Author: Mark Doty
Quote: Love, I think, is a gateway to the world, not an escape from it.

Author: Vladimir Lenin
Quote: Unity is a great thing and a great slogan. But what the workers’ cause needs is the unity of Marxists, not unity between Marxists, and opponents and distorters of Marxism.

Author: John Rawls,  Justice as Fairness: A Restatement
Quote: Many of our most serious conflicts are conflicts within ourselves. Those who suppose their judgements are always consistent are unreflective or dogmatic.

Author: Kahlil Gibran,  The Prophet
Quote: He who is more mindful of one, loses the love and the faith of both.

Author: Friedrich Nietzsche,  Beyond Good and Evil
Quote: To recognize untruth as a condition of life--that certainly means resisting accustomed value feelings in a dangerous way; and a philosophy that risks this would by that token alone place itself beyond good and evil.

Author: Dean Koontz,  Odd Thomas
Quote: Fate isn’t one straight road…there are forks in it, many different routes to different ends. We have the free will to choose the path.

Author: Paulo Coelho,  Veronika Decides to Die
Quote: You don't seem mad at all,' she said.But I am, although I'm undergoing a cure, because my problem is that I lack a particular chemical. However, while I hope that the chemical gets rid of my chronic depression, I want to continue being mad, living life the way I dream it, and not the way other people want it to be. Do you know what exists out there, beyond the walls of Villete?

Author: Margaret Atwood,  Der blinde Mörder
Quote: A Paradox, the doughnut hole. Empty space, once, but now they've learned to market even that. A minus quantity; nothing, rendered edible. I wondered if they might be used-metaphorically, of course-to demonstrate the existence of God. Does naming a sphere of nothingness transmute it into being?

Author: Norman Maclean,  A River Runs Through It and Other Stories
Quote: At sunrise everything is luminous but not clear.

Author: Norman Maclean,  A River Runs Through It and Other Stories
Quote: Yet even in the loneliness of the canyon I knew there were others like me who had brothers they did not understand but wanted to help. We are probably those referred to as "our brother's keepers,"possessed of one of the oldest and possible one of the most futile and certainly one of the most haunting instincts. It will not let us go.

Author: Albert Schweitzer
Quote: True philosophy must start from the most immediate and comprehensive fact of consciousness: 'I am life that wants to live, in the midst of life that wants to live

Author: Jean-Paul Sartre
Quote: Every existing thing is born without reason, prolongs itself out of weakness, and dies by chance.

Author: Mark Rowlands,  The Philosopher and the Wolf: Lessons from the Wild on Love, Death, and Happiness
Quote: In the end, it is our defiance that redeems us. If wolves had a religion – if there was a religion of the wolf – that it is what it would tell us.

Author: J.M. Coetzee,  The Lives of Animals
Quote: I want to find a way of speaking to fellow human beings that will be cool rather than heated, philosophical rather than polemical, that will bring enlightenment rather than seeking to divide us into the righteous and the sinners, the saved and the damned, the sheep and the goats.

Author: Kevin Alan Lee,  The Split Mind: Schizophrenia from an Insider's Point of View
Quote: In my opinion, our health care system has failed when a doctor fails to treat an illness that is treatable.

Author: E.E. Cummings
Quote: down with hell and heaven and all the religious fussinfinity pleased our parents one inch looks good to us

Author: Harshit Walia
Quote: Whole life is a search for beauty. But, when the beauty is found inside, the search ends and a beautiful journey begins.

Author: Jarod Kintz,  Love quotes for the ages. Specifically ages 18-81.
Quote: Escalators are the offspring of elevators and stairs. Love is the progeny of passion and admiration.

Author: Teri Hatcher,  Burnt Toast: And Other Philosophies of Life
Quote: Patience is the only way you can endure the gray periods.

Author: Luellen Hoffman
Quote: Life is a bitter sweet journey my friend, a bitter sweet journey.

Author: Julian Barnes,  The Sense of an Ending
Quote: Later on in life, you expect a bit of rest, don't you? You think you deserve it. I did, anyway. But then you begin to understand that the reward of merit is not life's business.

Author: Konrad Lorenz
Quote: Philosophers are people who know less and less about more and more, until they know nothing about everything. Scientists are people who know more and more about less and less, until they know everything about nothing.

Author: Sena Jeter Naslund,  Ahab's Wife, or The Star-Gazer
Quote: Where we choose to be, where we choose to be--we have the power to determine that in our lives. We cannot reel time backward or forward, but we can take ourselves to the place that defines our being.

Author: Herman Melville,  Moby Dick
Quote: Cannibals? Who is not a cannibal? I tell you it will be more tolerable for the Fejee that salted down a lean missionary in his cellar against a coming famine; it will be more tolerable for that provident Fejee, I say, in the day of judgement, than for thee, civilized and enlightened gourmand, who nailest geese to the ground and feastest on their bloated livers in thy pate de fois gras.

Author: Niccolò Machiavelli,  The Prince
Quote: A prince must not have any other object nor any other thought… but war, its institutions, and its discipline; because that is the only art befitting one who commands.

Author: Wallace Stevens,  Opus Posthumous: Poems, Plays, Prose
Quote: The final belief is to believe in a fiction, which you know to be a fiction, there being nothing else. The exquisite truth is to know that it is a fiction and that you believe in it willingly.

Author: Samuel Taylor Coleridge
Quote: No man was ever yet a great poet, without at the same time being a profound philosopher.

Author: Laurell K. Hamilton,  Incubus Dreams
Quote: I used to think I knew what was right and what was wrong, and who the good guys are, and who the bad guys are. Then the world got very gray, and I didn't know anything for a long time

Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
Quote: No law can be sacred to me but that of my nature. Good and bad are but names very readily transferable to that or this; the only right is what is after my constitution; the only wrong is what is against it.

Author: Friedrich Nietzsche,  Untimely Meditations
Quote: One has to take a somewhat bold and dangerous line with this existence: especially as, whatever happens, we are bound to lose it.

Author: Anatole France,  The Crime of Sylvestre Bonnard
Quote: Time deals gently only with those who take it gently.

Author: Dejan Stojanovic,  The Sun Watches the Sun
Quote: Even if you are alone you wage war with yourself.

Author: Gregory Bassham,  The Ultimate Harry Potter and Philosophy: Hogwarts for Muggles
Quote: To pursue wisdom is to live in such a way that one is prepared to face death when it comes. (247)

Author: Stephen King,  The Gunslinger
Quote: Why' is a crooked letter and can't be made straight.

Author: Jen Knox,  After the Gazebo
Quote: Only by examining our personal biases can we truly grow as artists; only by cultivating empathy can we truly grow as people.

Author: Max Lucado,  Traveling Light: Releasing the Burdens You Were Never Intended to Bear
Quote: Philosophers can debate the meaning of life, but you need a Lord who can declare the meaning of life.

Author: Scott Hahn,  Lord, Have Mercy: The Healing Power of Confession
Quote: We...sin not because we want what is evil, but because we want what isn't good enough.

Author: José Saramago
Quote: Because each of you has his or her own death, you carry it with you in a secret place from the moment you're born, it belongs to you and you belong to it.

Author: Horace
Quote: Pactum serva"- "Keep the faith

Author: Nenia Campbell,  Terrorscape
Quote: We feel most alive when we are closest to death.

Author: Mark Twain,  Life on the Mississippi
Quote: There is something fascinating about science. One gets such wholesale returns of conjecture out of such a trifling investment of fact.

Author: Carroll Bryant
Quote: I strive for perfection - I settle for satisfaction

Author: Diogenes of Sinope
Quote: It is not that I am mad, it is only that my head is different from yours.

Author: Aberjhani,  The River of Winged Dreams
Quote: Quote words that affirmall men and women are yourbrothers and sisters.

Author: Charlie Chaplin
Quote: I don't think the real America is in New York or on the Pacific Coast; personally, I like the Middle West much better, places like North and South Dakota, Minneapolis and Saint Paul. There, I think, are the true Americans

Author: Michael Collins
Quote: I knew I was alone in a way that no earthling has ever been before.

Author: Joel Salatin,  Everything I Want to Do Is Illegal: War Stories from the Local Food Front
Quote: When faith in our freedom gives way to fear of our freedom, silencing the minority view becomes the operative protocol.

Author: Colin Meloy,  Wildwood
Quote: We are the inheritors of a wonderful world, a beautiful world, full of life and mystery, goodness and pain. But likewise are we the children of an indifferent universe. We break our own hearts imposing our moral order on what is, by nature, a wide web of chaos.

Author: Arthur Schopenhauer
Quote: How very paltry and limited the normal human intellect is, and how little lucidity there is in the human consciousness, may be judged from the fact that, despite the ephemeral brevity of human life, the uncertainty of our existence and the countless enigmas which press upon us from all sides, everyone does not continually and ceaselessly philosophize, but that only the rarest of exceptions do.

Author: Peter Kreeft,  Pocket Handbook of Christian Apologetics
Quote: We can't avoid reasoning; we can only avoid doing it well.

Author: Vladimir Nabokov,  Bend Sinister
Quote: The square root of I is I.

Author: Plato
Quote: Philosophy is the highest music.

Author: René Daumal
Quote: I am dead because I lack desire,I lack desire because I think I possess.I think I possess because I do not try to give.In trying to give, you see that you have nothing;Seeing that you have nothing, you try to give of yourself;Trying to give of yourself, you see that you are nothing:Seeing that you are nothing, you desire to become;In desiring to become, you begin to live.

Author: Albert Camus
Quote: There is but one true philosophical problem and that is suicide.

Author: Daniel Quinn,  Ishmael: An Adventure of the Mind and Spirit
Quote: You're captives of a civilizational system that more or less compels you to go on destroying the world in order to live. … You are captives—and you have made a captive of the world itself. That's what's at stake, isn't it?—your captivity and the captivity of the world.

Author: Seneca
Quote: The best ideas are common property

Author: Plato
Quote: Ideas are the source of all things

Author: Francis Bacon
Quote: the serpent if it wants to become the dragon must eat itself.

Author: Marcus Aurelius,  Meditations
Quote: All things fade and quickly turn to myth.

Author: Ludwig Wittgenstein
Quote: An honest religious thinker is like a tightrope walker. He almost looks as though he were walking on nothing but air. His support is the slenderest imaginable. And yet it really is possible to walk on it.

Author: Brad Pitt
Quote: I'm probably 20 percent atheist and 80 percent agnostic. I don't think anyone really knows. You'll either find out or not when you get there, until then there's no point thinking about it.

Author: Guy Debord,  The Society of the Spectacle
Quote: The more powerful the class, the more it claims not to exist.

Author: Will Durant,  The Story of Philosophy
Quote: And last are the few whose delight is in meditation and understanding; who yearn not for goods, nor for victory, but for knowledge; who leave both market and battlefield to lose themselves in the quiet clarity of secluded thought; whose will is a light rather than a fire, whose haven is not power but truth: these are the men of wisdom, who stand aside unused by the world.

Author: Ali Shariati
Quote: I like Dancing of Indian girls more than my parents’ prayers . Because they dance with love and passion . But my parents just say their prayers because they got used to it .

Author: Solon
Quote: Call no man happy until he is dead.

Author: Richard Bach
Quote: The mark of your ignorance is the depth of your belief in injustice and tragedy. What the caterpillar calls the end of the world, the master calls a butterfly.

Author: Ray Bradbury,  Fahrenheit 451
Quote: Cram them full of non-combustible data, chock them so damned full of 'facts' they feel stuffed, but absolutely 'brilliant' with information. Then they’ll feel they’re thinking, they’ll get a sense of motion without moving. And they’ll be happy, because facts of that sort don’t change. Don’t give them any slippery stuff like philosophy or sociology to tie things up with. That way lies melancholy.

Author: Joel Salatin,  Everything I Want to Do Is Illegal: War Stories from the Local Food Front
Quote: The stronger a culture, the less it fears the radical fringe. The more paranoid and precarious a culture, the less tolerance it offers.

Author: Edgar Allan Poe,  The Black Cat
Quote: Who has not, a hundred times, found himself committing a vile or silly action for no other reason than because he knows he should not? Have we not a perpetual inclination, in the teeth of our best judgement, to violate that which is Law, merely because we understand it to be such?

Author: نجيب محفوظ,  أولاد حارتنا
Quote: للحياة أطواراً لا يخبرها المرء إلا يوماً بيوم

Author: Ayn Rand,  Atlas Shrugged
Quote: We are born into this world unarmed - our mind is our only weapon.

Author: Jostein Gaarder,  The Solitaire Mystery
Quote: If just one of [those people] experiences life as a crazy adventure--and I mean that he, or she, experiences this every single day... Then he or she is a joker in a pack of cards.

Author: Shane Koyczan
Quote: You see, the deaf have an intimacy with silence. It’s there in their dreams.

Author: Criss Jami,  Killosophy
Quote: Whenever I think of something but can't think of what it was I was thinking of, I can't stop thinking until I think I'm thinking of it again. I think I think too much.

Author: Jennifer Love Hewitt
Quote: Death isn't the end, it's the beginning.

Author: Richard Feynman
Quote: I believe that a scientist looking at nonscientific problems is just as dumb as the next guy.

Author: M.D. Birmingham
Quote: The love of money is the root of all evil, therefore selfishness must be the seed.

Author: Epicurus
Quote: He who says either that the time for philosophy has not yet come or that it has passed is like someone who says that the time for happiness has not yet come or that it has passed.

Author: Nikola Telsa,  The Problem of Increasing Human Energy
Quote: Our virtues and our failings are inseparable, like force and matter. When they separate, man is no more.

Author: Haruki Murakami,  Pinball, 1973
Quote: Me, I've seen 45 years, and I've only figured out one thing. That's this: if a person would just make the effort, there's something to be learned from everything. From even the most ordinary, commonplace things, there's always something you can learn. I read somewhere that they said there's even different philosophies in razors. Fact is, if it weren't for that, nobody'd survive.

Author: Emme Rollins,  Dear Rockstar
Quote: The best things in life are crazy.

Author: Plato,  Phaedrus
Quote: Only a philosopher's mind grows wings, since its memory always keeps it as close as possible to those realities by being close to which the gods are divine.

Author: Anne Rice,  Memnoch the Devil
Quote: Do you know what I think about crying? I think some people have to learn to do it. But once you learn, once you know how to really cry, there's nothing quite like it. I feel sorry for those who don't know the trick. It's like whistling or singing.

Author: Friedrich Nietzsche
Quote: I consist of body and soul - in the worlds of a child. And why shouldn't we speak like children? But the enlightened, the knowledgealbe would say: I am body through and through, nothing more; and the soul is just a word for something on the body.

Author: Friedrich Nietzsche
Quote: I have forgotten my umbrella.

Author: Friedrich Nietzsche,  The Will to Power
Quote: It is a self-deception of philosophers and moralists to imagine that they escape decadence by opposing it. That is beyond their will; and, however little they acknowledge it, one later discovers that they were among the most powerful promoters of decadence.

Author: Marie Symeou
Quote: We do not create life, we create death.

Author: John Guare,  Six Degrees of Separation
Quote: I believe that the imagination is the passport we create to take us into the real world. I believe the imagination is another phrase for what is most uniquely us.

Author: Walter Benjamin
Quote: Every passion borders on the chaotic, but the collector's passion borders on the chaos of memories.

Author: John Chrysostom
Quote: We follow the ways of wolves, the habits of tigers: or, rather we are worse than they. To them nature has assigned that they should be thus fed, while God has honoured us with rational speech and a sense of equity. And yet we are become worse than the wild beast.

Author: Søren Kierkegaard
Quote: The stone that was rolled before Christ's tomb might appropriately be called the philosopher's stone because its removal gave not only the pharisees but, now for 1800 years, the philosophers so much to think about.

Author: Albert Camus,  The Stranger
Quote: Mother used to say that however miserable one is, there’s always something to be thankful for. And each morning, when the sky brightened and light began to flood my cell, I agreed with her.

Author: Pema Chödrön
Quote: My experience with forgiveness is that it sort of comes spontaneously at a certain point and to try to force it it's not really forgiveness. It's Buddhist philosophy or something spiritual jargon that you're trying to live up to but you're just using it against yourself as a reason why you're not okay.

Author: Søren Kierkegaard,  Either/Or: A Fragment of Life
Quote: What is existence for but to be laughed at if men in their twenties have already attained the utmost?

Author: Fyodor Dostoyevsky,  The Brothers Karamazov
Quote: Men are made for happiness, and he who is completely happy has the right to say to himself, 'I am doing God's will on earth.

Author: Bertrand Russell,  The Problems of Philosophy
Quote: Whoever wishes to become a philosopher must learn not to be frightened by absurdities.

Author: Ambrose Bierce,  The Unabridged Devil's Dictionary
Quote: NIHILIST, n. A Russian who denies the existence of anything but Tolstoi. The leader of the school is Tolstoi.

Author: Guy Debord
Quote: Ideas improve. The meaning of words participates in the improvement. Plagiarism is necessary. Progress implies it. It embraces an author's phrase, makes use of his expressions, erases a false idea, and replaces it with the right idea.

Author: Søren Kierkegaard
Quote: Out of love for mankind, and out of despair at my embarrassing situation, seeing that I had accomplished nothing and was unable to make anything easier than it had already been made, and moved by a genuine interest in those who make everything easy, I conceived it as my task to create difficulties everywhere.

Author: Marcus Tullius Cicero,  De Divinatione
Quote: Sed nescio quo modo nihil tam absurde dici potest quod non dicatur ab aliquo philosphorum. (There is nothing so absurd but some philosopher has said it.)

Author: Albert Camus,  The Myth of Sisyphus and Other Essays
Quote: Beginning to think is beginning to be undermined. Society has but little connection with such beginnings. The worm is in man's heart. That is where it must be sought. One must follow and understand this fatal game that leads from lucidity in the face of existence to flight from light.

Author: H.L. Mencken
Quote: A philosopher is a blind man in a dark room looking for a black cat that isn't there. A theologian is the man who finds it.

Author: Rabindranath Tagore,  Gitanjali: Song Offerings
Quote: Deliverance is not for me in renunciation. I feel the embrace of freedom in a thousand bonds of delight.

Author: Epicurus
Quote: Empty is the argument of the philosopher which does not relieve any human suffering.

Author: Martha Grimes,  Dakota
Quote: Before you hate something you should try to understand it.

Author: Jostein Gaarder,  Sophie's World
Quote: A lot of people experience the world with the same incredulity as when a magician pulls a rabbit out of a hat.…We know that the world is not all sleight of hand and deception because we are in it, we are part of it. Actually we are the white rabbit being pulled out of the hat. The only difference beween us and the white rabbit is that the rabbit does not realize it is taking part in a magic trick.

Author: Gary D. Schmidt,  The Wednesday Wars
Quote: You can't just skip the boring parts.""Of course I can skip the boring parts.""How do you know they're boring if you don't read them?""I can tell.""Then you can't say you've read the whole play.""I think I can live a happy life, Meryl Lee, even if I don't read the boring parts of The Tragedy of Hamlet, Prince of Denmark.""Who knows?"she said. "Maybe you can't.

Author: Heraclitus
Quote: All are one

Author: Ludwig Wittgenstein
Quote: Don't think, but look! (PI 66)

Author: Kaiden Blake
Quote: YOU. ARE. PERFECT. You are. Im talking to YOU. and dont you dare think otherwise...embrace the entity of yourself...you are a puzzle piece and you are meant to be puzzling.

Author: Samuel Beckett
Quote: Words are the clothes thoughts wear.

Author: Richard M. Rorty
Quote: There is nothing deep down inside us except what we have put there ourselves.

Author: Stanisław Lem
Quote: If a man who can’t count finds a four leaf clover, is he lucky?

Quote: Because it's much more pleasant to be obsessed over how the hero gets out of his predicament than it is over how I get out of mine.

Author: Haven Kimmel,  The Solace Of Leaving Early
Quote: Possibility, infinity, beauty -- none of those words were right. [...] What he really wanted to say was: have you felt this? this phantom life streaking like a phosphorescent hound at the edges of your ruin?

Author: Georges Bataille,  Theory of Religion
Quote: The power of death signifies that this real world can only have a neutral image of life, that life's intimacy does not reveal it's dazzling consumption until the moment it gives out.

Author: Mervyn Peake,  Collected Poems
Quote: I, while the gods laugh, the world's vortex am;Maelström of passions in that hidden seaWhose waves of all-time lap the coasts of me;And in small compass the dark waters cram.- I, While the Gods Laugh, the World's Vortex Am

Author: Douglas Coupland,  The Gum Thief
Quote: ...we're told by TV and Reader's Digest that a crisis will trigger massive personal change--and that those big changes will make the pain worthwhile. But from what he could see, big change almost never happens. People simply feel lost. They have no idea what to say or do or feel or think. they become messes and tend to remain messes.

Author: فريدريك نيتشه,  هكذا تكلم زرادشت
Quote: إنكم تنظرون إلى ما فوقكم عندما تتشوقون إلى الاعتلاء،اما انا فقد علوت حتى أصبحت اتطلع إلى ما تحت أقدامي فهل فيكم من يمكنه أن يضحك وهو واقف على الذرى..من يحوم فوق أعالي الجبال يستهزئ بجميع مآسي الحياة ويستهزئ بمسارحها بل بالحياة نفسها

Author: Socrates
Quote: Are you not ashamed of caring so much for the making of money and for fame and prestige, when you neither think nor care about wisdom and truth and the improvement of your soul?

Author: Michael Bassey Johnson
Quote: You can believe in whatsoever you like, but the truth remains the truth, no matter how sweet the lie may taste.

Author: Debasish Mridha
Quote: Always be friendly, always be kind,Like the most beautiful flower that you can find.

Author: Virgil
Quote: Omnia vincit amor"- "Love conquers all

Author: Daniel Quinn,  Ishmael: An Adventure of the Mind and Spirit
Quote: The mythology of your culture hums in your ears so constantly that no one pays the slightest bit of attention to it. Of course man is conquering space and the atom and the deserts and the oceans and the elements. According to your mythology, this is what he was BORN to do.

Author: Mortimer J. Adler,  How to Read a Book: The Classic Guide to Intelligent Reading
Quote: The complexities of adult life get in the way of the truth. The great philosophers have always been able to clear away the complexities and see simple distinctions - simple once they are stated, vastly difficult before. If we are to follow them we too must be childishly simple in our questions - and maturely wise in our replies.

Author: Nick Harkaway,  Angelmaker
Quote: And don't tell me the end justifies the means because it doesn't. We never reach the end. All we ever get is means. That's what we live with.

Author: Guy Debord,  The Society of the Spectacle
Quote: The more he identifies with the dominant images of need, the less he understands his own life and his own desires. The spectacle’s estrangement from the acting subject is expressed by the fact that the individual’s gestures are no longer his own; they are the gestures of someone else who represents them to him.

Author: B.W. Powe,  Towards A Canada Of Light
Quote: Each voice carries a portion of value, no matter how unpalatable or distasteful that voice may be: no one person, government, ideology, transnational, or religious institution can own and dominate the whole.

Author: Yann Martel,  Beatrice and Virgil
Quote: Slice a pear and you will find that its flesh is incandescent white. It glows with inner light. Those who carry a knife and a pear are never afraid of the dark.

Author: Ayn Rand
Quote: An attempt to achieve the good by force is like an attempt to provide a man with a picture gallery at the price of cutting out his eyes.

Author: Charles Sanders Peirce
Quote: Upon this first, and in one sense this sole, rule of reason, that in order to learn you must desire to learn, and in so desiring not be satisfied with what you already incline to think, there follows one corollary which itself deserves to be inscribed upon every wall of the city of philosophy: Do not block the way of inquiry.

Author: Confucius,  The Wisdom Of Confucius
Quote: It is when those who are not strong enough have made some moderate amount of progress that they fail and give up...

Author: Friedrich Nietzsche
Quote: A nation is a detour of nature to arrive at five or six great men- yes, and then to get around them.

Author: N.K. Jemisin,  The Hundred Thousand Kingdoms
Quote: You are what your creators and experiences have made you, like every other being in this universe. Accept that and be done; I tire of your whining.

Author: Stephen K. Hayes
Quote: The warrior learns of the spiritual realm by dwelling on the cutting edge of the sword, standing at the edge of the fire pit, venturing right up to the edge of starvation if necessary. Vibrant and intense living is the warrior's form of worship.

Author: Victor Hugo,  Les Misérables
Quote: where the telescope ends the microscope begins, and who can say which has the wider vision?

Author: Albert Camus,  The Plague
Quote: Do you believe in God, doctor?"No - but what does that really mean? I'm fumbling in the dark, struggling to make something out. But I've long ceased finding that original.

Author: Niccolò Machiavelli,  The Prince - Niccolo Machiavelli - Original Version
Quote: I hold strongly to this: that it is better to be impetuous than circumspect; because fortune is a woman and if she is to be submissive it is necessary to beat and coerce her.

Author: Thomas Sowell
Quote: It doesn't matter how smart you are unless you stop and think.

Author: Santosh Kalwar
Quote: You like me not because I like you. I like you just because I like me.

Author: Pierre Teilhard de Chardin,  Hymn of the Universe
Quote: He recognized with absolute certainty the empty fragility of even the noblest theorizings as compared with the definitive plenitude of the smallest fact grasped in its total, concrete reality.

Author: Jasper Fforde,  One of Our Thursdays Is Missing
Quote: the Real-World was a sprawling mess of a book in need of a good editor.

Author: Erich Fromm,  To Have or to Be? The Nature of the Psyche

Author: Noah Levine,  Dharma Punx: A Memoir

Author: Isaac Newton

Author: Noah Levine,  Dharma Punx: A Memoir

Author: Andrei Pleșu
Quote: Trebuie sa te departezi putin de tine ca sa te poti apropia de ceilalti.

Author: Peter Singer,  Animal Liberation

Author: Santosh Kalwar

Author: Kahlil Gibran,  The Prophet

Author: Gene Roddenberry
Quote: Can all this just be an accident? Or could there be some alien intelligence behind it?

Author: Charlaine Harris,  Definitely Dead
Quote: There’s no way you can kill someone and get to the other side of the experience unchanged.

Author: Kahlil Gibran,  The Prophet

Author: Catherine Doyle,  Vendetta

Imagine if we had no secrets, no respite from the truth. What if everything was laid bare the moment we introduced ourselves?

Author: Arthur Schopenhauer,  The Wisdom of Life
Quote: There is not much to be got anywhere in the world. It is filled with misery and pain; if a man escapes these, boredeom lies in wait for him at every corner. Nay more; it is evil which generally has the upper hand, and folly that makes the most noise. Fate is cruel and mankind pitiable.

Author: توفيق الحكيم,  براكسا أو مشكلة الحكم

Author: Stefan Molyneux

We can choose our tribe, but we cannot change that our tribe is our destiny.

Author: A.S. Neill

Author: Mary Wortley Montagu

Author: Graham Parke,  No Hope for Gomez!

It was only when I found myself writing things I didn't realise I knew that I said, 'I'm a writer now.' The novel had become an incentive to deeper thinking. That's really what writing is—an intense form of thought.

Author: Pope John Paul II,  Blessed Are the Pure of Heart: Catechesis on the Sermon on the Mount and Writings of St. Paul

Author: Gilles Deleuze,  A Thousand Plateaus: Capitalism and Schizophrenia

Author: Noah Levine

Author: Friedrich Nietzsche,  Untimely Meditations

Author: كونفوشيوس

Author: Sherman Alexie,  War Dances

Author: Martin Buber

Author: Joseph de Maistre

Author: Criss Jami,  Killosophy

Author: Doug Dillon

Author: Robert Penn Warren

Author: Stefan Molyneux

Author: Guy Debord

Author: John Stuart Mill,  On Liberty

Author: Criss Jami,  Killosophy

Author: Susan Vreeland,  Clara and Mr. Tiffany

Author: Ayn Rand,  Atlas Shrugged

Author: Peter Kreeft,  Jesus-Shock

Author: Olaf Stapledon,  Odd John

Quote: Your educators can only be your liberators.

Author: Jeremy Bentham,  The Panopticon Writings

Author: C.B. Smith

Author: David Hume
Quote: Stercus accidit.

Author: Fulton J. Sheen

Author: Frank Herbert,  Dune

Author: William James

Author: Paul Tillich

Author: Lewis Carroll

Author: Henry David Thoreau
Quote: Disobedience is the true foundation of liberty.

Author: Aleister Crowley,  Cocaine: Impressions & Opinions

Author: Friedrich Nietzsche

Author: George Orwell

Author: Baruch Spinoza,  Ethics

Author: G.I. Gurdjieff,  Views from the Real World: Early Talks Moscow Essentuki Tiflis Berlin London Paris NY Chicago as Recollecte

Author: Robert Owen

Author: Criss Jami,  Killosophy

Author: Aristophanes,  Frogs and Other Plays

Author: Alfred North Whitehead

Author: Aristotle,  The Nicomachean Ethics

Author: Ludwig Wittgenstein,  Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus

Author: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe

Author: Robert Musil

Author: Daniel C. Dennett,  Darwin's Dangerous Idea: Evolution and the Meanings of Life
Quote: Problems in science are sometimes made easier by adding complications.

Author: Peter Kreeft,  Jesus-Shock

Author: Sophocles,  White Lies

Author: Ron Rash,  Serena

Author: Carroll Bryant
Quote: Believe in the wonderment of life, the magic of love, and the reality of death.

Author: Aaron Copland

Author: Teresa of Ávila

Author: Amit Kalantri

Author: Elif Shafak

Author: O.R. Melling
Quote: Hope burns eternal in the human heart.

Author: Walt Whitman,  Leaves of Grass

Author: Albert Camus

Author: Lafcadio Hearn

Author: Victor Hugo,  Les Misérables - anthology
Quote: When the heart is dry the eye is dry.

Author: Diogenes of Sinope,  The Lives and Opinions of Eminent Philosophers
Quote: I am a citizen of the world.

And that is why it's easy for rabid environmentalists to hate chainsaws even though they snuggle into a mattress supported by a black walnut bedstead.

The priest saw that there is no man who is elect because there is no man who is not. To God every man is a heretic.

Author: Ayn Rand
Quote: Definitions are the guardians of rationality, the first line of defense against the chaos of mental disintegration.

Author: Jacques Maritain,  An Introduction to Philosophy

Author: Isaac Newton

Author: Cristiane Serruya,  The Modern Man: A philosophical divagation about the evil banality of daily acts

Author: Ayn Rand

Author: Jean-François Lyotard

Author: Stefan Molyneux

Author: James S. Kunen,  The Strawberry Statement: Notes of a College Revolutionary

Author: Okakura Kakuzō,  The Book of Tea

Author: Cyrus the Great

Author: Prosper Mérimée,  Carmen

Author: Theodor W. Adorno

Author: Bertrand Russell,  A History of Western Philosophy

At last, with immense effort, he wrote down the secret before the vision had faded. When completely recovered, he rushed to see what he had written. It was: "A smell of petroleum prevails throughout.

Author: Paulo Coelho,  The Alchemist

Author: Ayn Rand

Author: Alvin Plantinga,  Warranted Christian Belief

Author: John Berry

When people believe that they have absolute knowledge, with no test in reality, this is how they behave.

Author: Deepak Chopra,  The Way of the Wizard: Twenty Spiritual Lessons for Creating the Life You Want

Author: Bertrand Russell

Author: J.T.Abraham

Author: Dejan Stojanovic,  The Sun Watches the Sun

Author: Jonas Eriksson

Author: Epicurus

Author: Amish Tripathi,  The Secret of the Nagas

Author: Elif Shafak

Author: Albert Schweitzer

Author: Grady Nutt
Quote: Laughter is the hand of God on the shoulder of a troubled world.

Author: Henry Miller,  Tropic of Capricorn

Author: Marcel Proust

Author: Daniel C. Dennett,  Freedom Evolves

Author: Helen Simonson,  Major Pettigrew's Last Stand

Author: Benny Bellamacina

The richer people at the top of a society become, supposedly, the more wealth there is to trickle down to the people below. It never really works out that way, of course, because if there are 2 things people at the top can't stand, they have to be leakage and overflow.

Author: Ilyas Kassam
Quote: The Purpose of Philosophy is to fall in Love. To strip the world of all its clothes, and fall in Love with it as it stand before you completely naked.

Author: Pablo

There’s no time to dwell on a missed opportunity or worry about what I should’ve done or said, beating myself up & making myself miserable about my mistakes. That doesn’t work. So will take notes from that, put it behind me, move on & finish the year STRONG
